meeting_annotations.speaker: Kristen Maitland
meeting_annotations.transcript: So one thing, so scattering in tissue or in your sample affects both your illumination and your ability to focus to a spot.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Kristen Maitland
meeting_annotations.transcript: And it also affects your collection. Um, and so, you know, there's some approaches to try to, um, control the light going to your spot to enhance your ability to focus to that tight spot or or to, um, improve your illumination.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Kristen Maitland
meeting_annotations.transcript: That depends, but you could, so for example, if you use some information, um, like if you're imaging in fluorescence, but you collect some information using the reflectance, you know, without you're going through your filters, that might be one aspect.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Kristen Maitland
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, so I think, um, it it would take a big picture look at what are you trying to do, what are is your imaging system or your microscope that you're trying to use and, um, how is scattering affecting your ability to image what you're trying to see.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Kristen Maitland
meeting_annotations.transcript: or image at a depth, you know, that maybe you can't reach. Um, and then taking into into consideration your sample that the light is traveling through and how does that in influence or impact your ability to image, whether it be resolution or depth or field of view.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Lew
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, maybe to to jump off that and and bridge back to what, uh, what Sishian was talking about at the beginning.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Lew
meeting_annotations.transcript: Like if we're in the fluorescence and, uh, some of the light from your floor for gets multiply scattered.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Lew
meeting_annotations.transcript: There's kind of two ways that we might think of detecting it. One is just waiting long enough because those multiply scattered photons would take longer to get to you. So you you kind of wait long enough and see where they landed and maybe those were your scattered photons.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Lew
meeting_annotations.transcript: The other thing that I think Josh is really better expert at is, um, if you change your imaging instrument in some way because that light was determinate that scattering was deterministic, like the cell boundaries that the light scattered off of were at certain some place relative to your imaging system.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Lew
meeting_annotations.transcript: If you change the instrument a little bit to better leverage those scattering patterns and get more light out now and get more light in, then you have a signature for for for fixing your image a little bit. So the the the imaging problem becomes harder now because it's no longer a uh, uh, optically engineered perfect objective that does your job for you.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Lew
meeting_annotations.transcript: Now you've got to reoptimize the imaging system on the fly for your specific sample and then you got to make sure that whatever you thought the scattering was from, wherever it was from and whenever it was from, like that's actually what you're detecting because it in principle, at least with elastically scattered light, there's no way to identify it any other way. Like the the photon energy is going to be the same, right? And, uh, and so, yeah.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Josh Brake
meeting_annotations.transcript: There's also some interesting things with scattering connecting back to our conversation about numerical aperture, which counter, you know, counterintuitively scattering can actually help you.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Josh Brake
meeting_annotations.transcript: Because at the fundamental level, high NA is about high spatial frequencies is about high angle illumination and so scattering has a way of creating this for you because of the, you know, in strongly scattering tissue after you, you know, scatter enough, you're at lambda over two.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Josh Brake
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, so that I think is something else too that you make your your enemy, your friend in some sense by, you know, taking advantage of what's happening there and then maybe you maybe you decouple from the traditional connection with lenses between field of view and working depth and NA and the geometrical piece of lens design.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Josh Brake
meeting_annotations.transcript: There's only so many parameters you have to to tweak, but if you can think about your lens as a and I think Sishan will be, you know, with Laura, she always talks about like your lens is a Laura Waller, your lens is a matrix basically, which I love that like picture thinking about.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Josh Brake
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, you know, and in the wavefront shaping community, we think of like replacing a lens with a cube of salt or something like, you know, cube of sugar or something and just sending light through it and if you know what the, you know, the matrix is, mathematically there may be some interesting properties there that you can leverage that may actually help you and not hurt you.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Silvian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's a great point.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Silvian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, I was also doing post in Laura Waller's lab and uh I really like her perspective that.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Silvian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh, lens is just a face mask, right? So whatever whatever point spread function you want in the end, you can somehow and reverse engineer the lens you want.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Silvian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: And uh back to Dylan's question, that's actually really um, uh, I think it's also a very good point to start framing off. Um, so to solve the problem, I think we can start from two.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Silvian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh, one is detection, how can you reassign photons based on different properties, based on different characteristics of photons you capture.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Silvian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: And then second way is uh second way, how can you form the beam for? For example, for light sheet microscopy, it's very hard to get get a nice light sheet after scattering. So how can you use wavefront engineering or scattering compensation to get a nice illumination in the beginning.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Silvian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: So you don't worry that much about detection later. Um, my question is, um, like what is the fundamental limit in either direction.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Silvian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: So if we try all these methods and we push our depth like 10% more, is it worth it? Uh, and this applies for both um detection and illumination. Detection, you have photo photon starvation, you have noise issue and for illumination, um, no matter how much you compensate.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Silvian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: At some point you lose the correlation between photons and you lost uh at one point it's just random walk. So how much more can we push and what is the fundamental challenge in the in the field right now.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Kristen Maitland
meeting_annotations.transcript: And Luke, can we hear from you as well?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Luke Mortensen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, yeah, sure.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Luke Mortensen
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I I think I mean, I think that one of the challenges that I see is is like how much deeper can you go? How much further can you go is a major problem.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Luke Mortensen
meeting_annotations.transcript: But a a bigger problem that we've noticed is how long does it take you to get there? You know, because you can do a decent job of understanding what's happening to the light and like recreating a focus and then detecting whatever signal you get out. But you're really going to have to detect for a really long time to get enough photons out and overcome your SNR problems.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Luke Mortensen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Or it's going to take you quite a while to do the correction factor and even, you know, current best in class that's pretty, you know, for a whole organism or, you know, whether it's like the whole organism or just a whole organism.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Luke Mortensen
meeting_annotations.transcript: In both cases, you're looking at problems with, you know, signal and movement and time. And, um, you know, those those seem like like major issues.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Luke Mortensen
meeting_annotations.transcript: That in order to get it from the point of where it requires full um deconstruction of the organism, you know, which is definitely and a useful and insightful approach. Back to something that's maybe hopefully happening in a dynamic setting, we can understand like how things are are altering with time. Um, you know, sort of like our keynote talk is, I think, you know, trying to bridge those two two spectrum I I think is sort of is a challenge.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Dylan Burnette
meeting_annotations.transcript: But if you're trying to detect things in multiple dimensions, let's just say time, if things are going to take longer to get there.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Dylan Burnette
meeting_annotations.transcript: Is it possible that you could just use multiple detectors? Because when we when we go and put two cameras on our system, we want them to be par focal basically. We want to them to be in in the exact same focal plane.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Dylan Burnette
meeting_annotations.transcript: But can you alternate the detectors to detect um things that take longer to get there? Just move the camera closer. I mean, can I don't know if if with with one detector we're going to be able to get to this thing and.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Dylan Burnette
meeting_annotations.transcript: And you and you guys are the physics people, but I can't imagine this is going to be solved with one camera. It's just going to take too darn long to image an organism.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Silvian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: You're definitely not crazy.
